description: It’s simply a fun reaction image showing a very enthusiastic toddler having a great time splashing around outdoors. The caption “ME WHEN I KNOW I GET TO SEE YOU” suggests the gif is used to express energetic excitement or joy about encountering someone special. Essentially, it conveys the feeling of being overjoyed and unable to contain one’s excitement when looking forward to seeing a person.

response.content: I am ai and gif professor.
arc is types of Abtract Reasoning Corpus, and you are professor. I should say things clearly and without fakes at all.

content.text: Hi GPT, can you explain this gif ?

response.content: It’s simply a fun reaction image showing a very enthusiastic toddler having a great time splashing around outdoors. The caption “ME WHEN I KNOW I GET TO SEE YOU” suggests the gif is used to express energetic excitement or joy about encountering someone special. Essentially, it conveys the feeling of being overjoyed and unable to contain one’s excitement when looking forward to seeing a person.

So, this is gif, so time-series image data. Can you under-size the image by 30x30? grid style. You may know how Abstraction and Reasoning Corpus look like. You can follow that style, but no input-output pair, but image1 -> image2 -> image 3 -> image n  (each image has same size of grid 30x30) just show me the first image (it can be represented as array)
Then, can you give me the highlight part of the pixelated gif with same 30x30 grid , you can provide me the matrix as well as generating image if you want.

Below is an example of an ARC-style problem (with grids up to 10×10) along with three training input-output pairs and one test input-output pair, plus a concise “analogy” (the rule) and a short DSL-based solution using Michael Hodel’s provided functions. 

──────────────────────────────────────────────────
1) ARC-Like Task
──────────────────────────────────────────────────

Task (in plain words):
“For each cell, if row_index + column_index is even, override its color with 9. Otherwise, leave the color as-is.”

Data (JSON-like structure):

{
  "train": [
    {
      "input": [
        [0,0,0],
        [0,2,0],
        [1,1,1]
      ],
      "output": [
        [9,0,9],
        [0,9,0],
        [9,1,9]
      ]
    },
    {
      "input": [
        [0, 1, 0, 0],
        [2, 0, 1, 3],
        [5, 5, 5, 5],
        [9, 9, 9, 9]
      ],
      "output": [
        [9, 1, 9, 0],
        [2, 9, 1, 9],
        [9, 5, 9, 5],
        [9, 9, 9, 9]
      ]
    },
    {
      "input": [
        [4,4,4,4,4],
        [1,1,5,1,1],
        [2,2,8,2,2]
      ],
      "output": [
        [9,4,9,4,9],
        [1,9,5,9,1],
        [9,2,9,2,9]
      ]
    }
  ],
  "test": [
    {
      "input": [
        [0,0,8,8,8],
        [1,1,1,1,1],
        [2,2,3,3,3],
        [0,1,0,1,0]
      ],
      "output": [
        [9,0,9,8,9],
        [1,9,1,9,1],
        [9,2,9,3,9],
        [0,9,0,9,0]
      ]
    }
  ]
}

──────────────────────────────────────────────────
2) Analogy / Rule
──────────────────────────────────────────────────
“If the sum of the cell’s row index and column index is even, repaint it with color 9. Otherwise, keep its original color.”

──────────────────────────────────────────────────
3) A Possible DSL Solution
──────────────────────────────────────────────────

Below is one way to solve the above puzzle using functions from the provided DSL (by Michael Hodel).  The key steps are:

• asindices(grid): get all (row, col) locations.  
• index(grid, (i, j)): get current color at location (i, j).  
• add(i, j): sum row and column.  
• even(n): check if n is even.  
• branch(condition, val_if_true, val_if_false).  
• paint(...): assemble the new grid.

--------------------------------------------------------------------------------
from arc_types import Grid, Object, asindices, index, add, even, branch, canvas, shape, paint, frozenset

def solve(grid: Grid) -> Grid:
    """
    For each cell (i, j) in 'grid', if (i + j) is even, color = 9.
    Otherwise, keep the original color. Then return the transformed grid.
    """
    # Gather all locations in the grid.
    locations = asindices(grid)

    # Build a new "object" (value, (i, j)) for each cell.
    # The color is decided by whether (i + j) is even.
    transformed_object = frozenset(
        ( branch(
             even(add(i, j)),    # condition 
             9,                  # if true
             index(grid, (i,j))  # if false
           ), (i, j))
        for (i, j) in locations
    )

    # Start from a blank canvas of the same shape, color it by painting the new object.
    blank = canvas(0, shape(grid))
    return paint(blank, transformed_object)
--------------------------------------------------------------------------------

By applying solve(...) to each input grid, we get the corresponding output grid exactly as shown in the training and test pairs.
